===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|い|おう}}
{{IPAchar|/juawa/}} → {{IPAchar|/juwau/}} → {{IPAchar|/iwau/}} → {{IPAchar|/iwɔː/}} → {{IPAchar|/iwoː/}} → {{IPAchar|/ioː/}}

Originally a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=いおう|湯|tr1=yu|t1=warm or hot water|泡|tr2=awa|t2=bubble}}, from the way that [[volcanic]] [[hot spring]]s would often be accompanied by bubbles of [[sulfur]] gas.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

The kanji spelling is an example of [[熟字訓#Japanese|jukujikun]].

An alternative theory is that the character {{m|ja|硫||sulfur}} developed an [[音読み|on'yomi]] of ''yu'' instead of the usual [[呉音#Japanese|goon]] of ''ru'' or [[漢音#Japanese|kan'on]] of ''ryū'', such that the reading is [[音読み|on'yomi]].<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>  However, given that this particular sound shift is not found in other kanji readings, this derivation seems unlikely.

This is the most common reading for this term in modern Japanese.

{{ja-pron|yomi=irr|いおう|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR,NHK}}

* {{ja-r|硫黄山|いおうやま}}: sulfur mine
* {{ja-r|硫黄泉|いおうせん}}: sulfur spring
* {{ja-r|硫黄酸化物|いおう さんかぶつ}}: sulfur oxide
* {{ja-r|塩化硫黄|えんかい いおう}}: sulfur chloride
* {{ja-r|三酸化硫黄|さんさんか いおう}}: sulfur trioxide
* {{ja-r|石灰硫黄合剤|せっかい いおう ごうざい}}: [[lime sulphur]]
* {{ja-r|二酸化硫黄|にさんか いおう}}: sulfur dioxide

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|ゆ|おう|sort=ゆおう}}
{{IPAchar|/juawa/}} → {{IPAchar|/juwau/}} → {{IPAchar|/juwɔː/}} → {{IPAchar|/juwoː/}} → {{IPAchar|/juoː/}}

Other than the difference in phonetic shifts, the derivation is the same as for ''iō'' above.

This reading is rare, and possibly archaic.
